intro: Ophrys × gumprechtii nothosubsp. pierae, commonly known as the hybrid bee orchid, is a rare and unusual plant resulting from the cross between Ophrys gumprechtii and Ophrys pierii. It is a member of the Orchidaceae family and exhibits typical orchid characteristics, including a slender stem and a single, showy flower. The plant is notable for its mimicry of female wasps, a trait that aids in its pollination strategy by attracting male wasps. It thrives in specific alpine or subalpine habitats, often in rocky or limestone soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
